11:16 am
BE

BE

And "The same bad news repeated by different players is not 'more' bad news."

BE

Bears have commented on recent poor results from Pearson, Cengage, Wiley, Houghton Mifflin and Barnes & Noble Education. This has been presented in each case as incrementally bad news. We disagree. It is like the adage ‘ten years of experience or one year of experience ten times’. The issues being cited in each case are the same ones.

11:17 am
BE

(I'm guessing the "ten years of experience" thing is the kind of thing they say in management school.)

BE

(Because as an aphorism, it ain't the best.)

BE

Whichever way, here's the cover page.

11:17 am
BE

Down 25% from its highs and with a c10% 2018 FCF yield versus a p/e of 10x the market is expecting another profits warning. We don’t think Pearson will warn, meaning the shares could recover sharply on the Q3 results.

BE

Pearson – market fears another warning: Pearson shares have slumped since the H1 results on fears that lower H1 gross sales and higher returns in the US college business will lead Pearson to miss its 2016 guidance of pre restructuring cost EBITA of £580m-£620m, to abandon its 2018 £800m EBITA target and to cut its thinly covered dividend. The shares are down 25% since their recent peak and are the worst performing large dollar earner in the UK post the Brexit vote.

BE

Putting US Higher Ed in perspective: Higher Ed courseware is 27% of Pearson revenues and c32% of EBITA. The business will struggle in 2016 with fall enrolments still likely to be down 1-2% and college bookstores in cautious mode. Gross sales though should fall faster than net sales as caution in the retail channel implies lower overall returns. We have a 3% decline in HE courseware net sales in 2016. Even if this were -6%, and we assume a margin of 85% on the lost sales, the impact is just £30m on profits, equivalent to 5% in 2016, less than the £40m spread on Pearson’s forecast range.

11:18 am
BE

Why we are buyers: (i) Pearson cut market expectations by £35m-£75m pre restructuring (and £355m-£395m post restructuring) in January. This covers a multitude of sins. (ii) Pearson's EBITA forecasts have a lot of flex allowing, for instance, an increase of £110m in incentive compensation in 2016 – 18% of expected EBITA. (iii) Pearson strongly reiterated its 2016-18 guidance at the H1 figures and has not rescinded it in subsequent public appearances, the most recent being September 21. (iv) There is better trading elsewhere at Pearson with good growth in the digital businesses and better than expected contract wins in Assessment. (v) 2017 is an inevitable upswing year in US schools with a better environment in US Higher Ed (enrolments close to flat) and US and UK assessment. (vi) With 66% of sales in the US and sub 10% in the UK, Pearson is a play on Brexit nervousness. (vii) We think Pearson won't warn at Q3 (end October), the peak trading period. Given the underperformance, low rating and big dividend yield – almost 7% – we think the shares will bounce strongly on this.

BE

Too cheap: At 760p Pearson trades at a 2017 p/e of 11.4x, virtually its low point relative to the market in the last decade. The FCF yield is 8.6% and the dividend yield 6.8%. By 2018 the p/e of 10.2x barely exceeds the FCF yield of 9.8%. At our 1050p target Pearson would trade at 14x 2018 (average ten year multiple of 14.3x), a FCF yield of 7% and dividend yield of 5%.

PM

BE

This is all a point made by Barclays.

11:23 am
BE

The Pearson story hangs on the performance of North America Higher Ed
Courseware in Q3. Last year, a surprisingly bad Q3 was a hit to confidence. This year
the market expects a repeat: 1) the shares have underperformed FTSE 100 by 24%
since just before 1H, and 2) US College news in Q2 and July was negative from
Pearson, Cengage, Wiley and B&N Edu. But it is still plausible that lower textbook
returns could keep Q3 declines modest (-3-4%), which would be a relief. Visibility is
limited so this note does not take a view on Q3. Rather we aim to help investors
evaluate this unit, by digging into how revenues and profits build up and the key
issues. We conducted a survey of 50 US professors to inform our thinking. Our
conclusions are mixed. We have concerns on enrolments, the sustainability of
revenues per enrolment and operational gearing. We are more relaxed on Open
Educational Resources. We model a return to 1% growth in 2018 for NA HE
Courseware but not enough growth or operational gearing to hit 2018 guidance.
Then we run an Upside/Downside scenario on this division and apply appropriate
multiples to the implied group EPS. This yields upside potential of 52% and
downside of 20%: a skewed risk/reward. But 1) we have concerns about short-term
forecasts and 2) our scenarios focus on NA Higher Ed – but extra weakness would
hit confidence on the rest of Pearson. So we stay EW, with a SOTP-driven 750p PT.

BE

Investigating enrolments, OER, rental & bookstore channel issues: We conclude: 1)
enrolments may continue to decline for longer, factoring in employment participation
rate; 2) we are concerned bookstore destocking is not yet done; 3) we think high new
textbook price increases have offset drags from rental in particular, keeping rev per
enrolment flat (but this is not sustainable); and 4) OER risks remain small for now.

BE

But you get the idea.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 5,040, down 1 (-0.02%), High: 5,046, Low: 4,983, Volume: 1.04m

Underperforming quite a lot after Brilinta fails in peripheral artery disease

11:34 am

This is the EUCLID trial, phase 3, showing whether it's better than Plavix.

11:35 am

BE

We expect consensus to remove
~$300-400m from outer year sales, impacting earnings by 1-2%. While a
disappointment, AZN is about to enter a period of intense pipeline newsflow
over the next 12 months. Although short-term focus remains on its prospects
in the field of immuno-oncology ahead of read-out of the MYSTIC Phase III trial
of durvalumab/tremelimumab in 1L lung cancer (due 1H17), we continue to be
confident that in aggregate the next 12 months will see confidence in AZN’s
return to growth improve.

BE

The news is a further
disappointment following failure of the SOCRATES trial in the post stroke
setting earlier in 2016. As a reminder, the SOCRATES trial marginally missed
statistical significance in reducing risk of cardiovascular events versus
standard-of-care aspirin. Data from the EUCLID trial is expected to be
presented at the American Heart Association meeting in New Orleans,
Louisiana in November 2016. Detail of the data may have moderate
implications to physician perceptions of Brilinta’s proven superiority over Plavix
in other settings.

11:36 am
BE

Our 2022E forecasts for Brilinta sales of $1.9bn assume sales in the current
acute coronary syndrome (ACS) indication reach around $1.2bn, with a further
$700m coming from additional approvals in PAD and high-risk/diabetes
(~$350m each). Achievement of this is looking increasingly unlikely without
resounding success from the THEMIS trial due in 2018 (diabetes). However,
we remind investors that the recently expanded approval of Brilinta for
extended duration of therapy in ACS and an expected approval in Japan are
expected to drive near-term growth of the franchise.

BE

By the way, I think I might've said enthusiastic things about immuno-oncology in recent weeks.

BE

I've changed my mind.

11:37 am
BE

The sketchy and unpredictable results from immuno-oncology trials suggest they won't come anywhere close to the assumptions baked in by the sellside.

PM

(BornCynic -- we had a generalised tech melt-down -- sorry about tht)

BE

And basic research has already pretty much abandoned immuno-oncology as an avenue, because weaponising a patient's immune system just doesn't seem to work terribly well.

11:38 am
BE

So .... If you happened to read me two or so weeks ago on it ... forget that, I was wrong.

BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

AstraZeneca has announced that the EUCLID trial for Brilinta, which was looking
to expand the use of Brilinta into the Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) setting, has failed to
show any benefit over the use of clopidogrel (Plavix) in this setting. There were no safety
issues and this does not have any impact on its currently approved use in Acute Coronary
Syndrome patients or in the Post Myocardial Infarction setting. Brilinta had also previously
failed to show any incremental benefit in stroke following the failure of the SOCRATES study
in Mar’16. AstraZeneca had originally given a $3.5bn peak sales forecast for Brilinta at the
time of the Pfizer bid, but this has not been reiterated since the failure of the prior SOCRATES
stroke study. We currently model sales peaking in 2023E at c$1.9bn

11:41 am
PM

Head of uk rates at UBS

PM

INcoming...

PM

The pound has been trading in a narrow range but that is about to change
Since falling violently in the aftermath of the EU referendum in June, sterling has spent the past three months in a relatively narrow range. Even after today's drop it is not far below July's low. The recovery in several gauges of sentiment and activity after the immediate shock has prevented more material declines, but in our view it is only a matter of time before less positive data starts to appear.

The recent fall has cushioned the blow to sentiment but will generate inflation
As BoE Deputy Governor Nemat Shafik said in a recent speech, the depreciation in sterling – more than 15% below its prior peak in November 2015 – is "certainly helping the economy to find a new equilibrium" amid the uncertainty surrounding the nature of the UK's future trading arrangements with the EU, and as signs mount that foreign companies have become more cautious about investing in the UK. While the fall in sterling is helpful in this regard, the higher import prices it generates means inflation is likely to rise materially over the coming months.

With the labour market set to cool, the consumer will come under pressure
Survey evidence suggests many companies expect to adopt a more defensive approach to their business plans over the coming period of uncertainty (Figure1). Marked slowing in investment and hiring intentions point to a weaker labour market, with the Bank of England expecting a rise in unemployment from 4.9% to 5.6% over the next two years (Figure2). Wage inflation may subside as a result, and real earnings will slow sharply. Soft domestic private sector demand would weaken sterling over the next year.

11:42 am
PM

Current account deficit has improved slightly, but is still unsustainably large
Helped by the decline in sterling since last November, the UK current account deficit has improved from -7.0% of GDP in Q4 15 to -5.9% in Q2 16. We believe it will need to become significantly smaller during the period of high vulnerability that will persist at least for the two-year period between the triggering of Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty and the UK's formal exit from the EU. Further currency weakness would be the most benign driver of further declines in this deficit (Figure3).

As well as these economic headwinds, political risks are expected to intensify
The Prime Minister has confirmed that the formal process of the UK's exit from the EU will begin by the end of the first quarter of 2017 with the triggering of Article 50. As happened in the case of the referendum itself, the transformation of anticipated risk events from a high probability to a certainty, and from an unknown date to a confirmed one, can be a powerful catalyst for currency weakness (Figure5).

PM

Bank of England stands ready to do more if needed
While there are still mixed views among MPC members as to the possible need for additional stimulus, most of the key members of the Committee have expressed a willingness to continue acting pre-emptively in response to high uncertainty, and an expectation that more easing is likely to be necessary. Additional stimulus would likely drive further sterling weakness, as it did when sanctioned in early August.

2007/08 all over again?
Having fallen 13.4% between July 2007-March 2008, sterling has traded sideways for four months. When the global financial crisis entered its acute phase, sterling resumed its rapid decline, falling a further 20% by the end of 2008. Although different in its underlying causes, a similar pattern of decline, pause, and fresh falls may be unfolding now (Figure4). We reiterate our forecasts for the end of 2017 of $1.20 for GBP/USD (currently 1.288), and 1.00 for EUR/GBP (currently 0.874)

undefined

BE

Bit of sellside around on the challenger banks, if that's of interest at all.

PM

( Tsetse - can yo screenshot and share with me? paul.murphy@ft.com)

BE

(@roddy1234: yep, there might be something in that thought.)

11:44 am
BE

JP Morgan Caz starts coverage of Metro (with a sell) and Virgin (with a buy)

Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 2,845, up 29 (+1.03%), High: 2,855, Low: 2,785, Volume: 18.81k
BE

...... and I know we've asked this before, but what the hell is the deal with Metro since float?

11:45 am
BE

It's now at three times TBV. Why?

BE

Here's Caz.

BE

We believe that the current operating backdrop for UK domestic banks is
characterized by continued earnings pressure from low rates and legacy issues
with uncertainty around medium-term economic growth and downside risk to
London/South East asset prices. While near-term economic and banking
trends are resilient with limited changes to business momentum in 2016, we
are concerned that this may lead to a false sense of comfort as the real impact
of Brexit on the UK economy is unlikely to be clear until 2017/18. In this note
we map some of the challenges and opportunities in the current UK banking
environment, initiating coverage on Virgin Money (OW, PT 400p) which is
our preferred domestic UK bank and Metro Bank (UW, PT 2,600p) which we
view as fully valued. StanChart remains OW and top pick for 2016.

11:46 am
BE

Challenges require strategic action by large banks: Aside from the
overhang from litigation (RMBS & PPI), lower rate expectations along with
slower UK growth will depress revenue. Strategic actions include more cost
cuts, divestments and M&A – we believe market expectations for new
management action will increase in 2017 and see more cost cuts ahead.
M&A is also an option. If priced correctly, an acquisition of MBNA (cards)
could be a hedge against low rates for Lloyds or HSBC in our view.

BE

Selective investment opportunities still exist: Smaller, retail-focused banks
such as Virgin Money, CYBG, and Metro Bank do not have exposure to
legacy issues and can grow revenues as larger banks give up share. The
BOE’s TFS, which offers 4 year funding at 25bps for banks growing loans, is
helping lower deposit rates, which creates a NIM tailwind and allows banks
with Savings/Term deposits to offset margin pressure. However, neither the
TFS nor cheaper deposit funding is permanent and valuations for challenger
banks have already materially increased in the post referendum rally.

BE

Virgin Money – A UK retail growth story: We initiate coverage on Virgin
Money with an OW rating and PT of £4, offering c25% potential upside. We
believe that the group’s pure UK retail banking focused business model is
likely to underpin a relatively clean, high return and growing earnings
profile trading at a discount, 8x PE and 0.9x P/TNAV 18E for 12% RoTE.

11:46 am
BE

Cautious on Metro Bank and CYBG at current valuations. We initiate
on London & South East focused Metro Bank with an UW rating and PT of
2,600p and remain UW CYBG (PT 220p). While we are constructive on
Metro Bank's superior service focused growth strategy, we believe that
valuation is now pricing in all of the growth but none of the risks following
the c75% rally from the June lows. The shares trade at 3x/2x 2016/20E
P/TNAV, more than discounting the group’s 2020 targets.

Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 332.50, up 7.2 (+2.21%), High: 335.40, Low: 326.90, Volume: 500.07k
BE

As for the more obvious last-chance-saloon mortgage lenders ....

11:48 am
BE

.... Barclays pushing OSB and Aldermore.

OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 281.40, up 12.7 (+4.73%), High: 288.70, Low: 273.20, Volume: 315.60k
Aldermore Group PLC (ALD:LSE): Last: 177.50, up 1.9 (+1.08%), High: 181.80, Low: 176.80, Volume: 611.46k
11:49 am
BE

Upgrading OSB and ALD to OW: From July-15 to July-16 there was considerable anti-
Buy-To-Let (BTL) sentiment in the media. Some measures of control were perhaps
inevitable to slow rates of growth exceeding 40% yoy. However, we now believe we are
past the nadir for BTL outlook. We view further regulatory and taxation controls as
unlikely if the UK government does not want to risk pushing the economy into a post-
Brexit recession. We do not believe that a reversal of any BTL-related stamp or income
tax is likely in the Autumn Budget. But, providing no further controls are introduced,
favourable demographics can return and stimulate volumes. UK Challenger Banks
remain geared plays on the macro, in our view. However, high profitability, comfortable
capital ratios and low valuation multiples should provide significant insulation. For
these reasons, we upgrade OneSavings Bank to OW from EW as the purest play on BTL
originations, Aldermore to OW from EW due to its diversified model and rising
profitability. We remain EW on Shawbrook due to lingering concerns around controls
and provisions. Paragon is EW due to slow progress on back book run-off.

BE

BTL demographics remain highly favourable: In 2015 a raft of measures were
proposed to control BTL growth. In July-15 the focus was on reduced income tax
deductibility. In Nov-15 it was on raised stamp duty and in Dec-15 significantly raised
risk weights. We now believe the probably of risk weights rising from 35% to 70-120%
is very remote. A more minor increase may well be offset through moves to IRB.
Providing there are no further anti-BTL measures we highlight the demand and supply
demographics in the UK remain highly favourable. These mainly relate to lack of
ownership affordability and increased restrictions on owner-occupied mortgages, such
as controls on LTV and loan-to-income multiples which force renting for longer.

BE

BTL Affordability controls contain few surprises: On 29 Sep, the PRA announced
affordability control measures for BTL. We view these as sensible and largely consistent
with existing best practice. We do not believe that ICR tests of 125 over 5.5% will create
much of a volume slowdown. The definition of a professional landlord at 4 or more
properties with increased requirements to review the whole of a landlord’s
circumstances may actually encourage consolidation. Banks may be less willing to lend
on single BTL applications if they have to do due diligence over the whole of a portfolio.

11:49 am
BE

Low valuation multiples: Our average UK specialist lender is down -18% ytd with purer
UK Challenger Banks down 28-32%. Precautionary EPS downgrades have been milder
at 11% causing de-rating of these names. The avg FY16E PE multiple is only ~7x and
P/BV multiples are 1.0-1.7x for 20-30% ROE.
PT changes: Sector re-rating reflecting lower implied COE and EPS upgrades cause our
PTs to change for OSB from 235p to 340p, for ALD from 150p to 200p, for SHAW from
175p to 220p and for PAG from 275p to 320p.

BE

(@Damaging Director: apologies, I use Imgur image hosting for speed and convenience even though I know a bunch of bank nannywalls don't allow it.)

Jordan Rochester -- off with his head

PM

In the aftermath of the Brexit vote, a new cabinet was born, one that over time has seen
any hopes of following a path to a “soft Brexit” start to fade away. Statements from Brexit
ministers before the conference have been along the lines of “access to the single
market” but “control over immigration.” With little to no overlap between the two, it
resembles that of a disjointed Venn diagram, with the Hard Brexit set carrying the more
political weight. This is the reality that has been known for some time, though, so it’s
interesting to see GBP underperform to a new low this morning in the fashion that it has.
Reminded that the single market access is important, but not on top
The speech by Theresa May over the weekend told us that the timing of Article 50 is to
be “no later than the end of March next year.” This provided clarity as to when, but was
not much of a surprise given several reports that alluded to that possibility in the weeks
prior. The market view this morning was that the big themes of Brexit were touched on
and offered little hope of a single market access outcome, given the emphasis on
immigration and sovereignty controls used.
A confidence shock remains the risk to the growth outlook, but yet to materialize
It’s ironic that we question the growth outlook when this morning’s PMI data continues to
suggest that the UK is growing at, and perhaps above, trend as we head into Q4 and
higher than that of both the EU and US.

11:53 am
PM

The markets’ Hard Brexit realisation, how far can political uncertainty rise?

PM

The price action itself is reminiscent of when Boris Johnson came out in support of Brexit
in February and when the June date was announced. GBP fell on the Asian open even
though risk markets fared well, but really it was from 7am on the Monday when GBP
started to fall significantly, and vols head higher taking a week to find a base.
Looking past that, the political uncertainty remains high but it’s hard to see how it can get
much worse from here as the market has likely realized the higher risk of Hard Brexit
now. We are unlikely to learn of anything material apart from the aims stated already
until the negotiations start.
Positives in the data but risk events pose a downside tail risk
The UK is yet to show a material sign of a post-vote slowdown in the data, so
considering from now until the BOE meeting in November without any further negative
market uncertainty it’s a lesser chance the BOE will cut (with about 4bps of a cut priced)
that would naturally be GBP supportive.
However, GBP continues to trade with risk sentiment, and there are still a few events
from now until year-end that we would monitor. For reference, we’ve added a few of the
key tail risk dates both in and out of the UK below.

Events to watch out for
We’ll be keeping an eye the data, of course (Services PMI on Wednesday for example),
but on the politics side of things, we note the following:
 Article 50 legal challenge to be heard 13 and 17 October
i. A two-day hearing, with the opportunity to extend the length of the
hearing, will take place in mid-October (links here and here).
 UK Q3 GDP first estimate – 27 October
i. A growth rate of 0.0% would be in line with the August BOE
projections and, thus, in line with the view to cut at the November
meeting. Now-Casting efforts have Q3 GDP tracking above 0.45%.
 The US election - 8 November
i. Whilst Donald Trump’s TV debate performance has seen the market
lower the probability of his win, it’s still an event to watch out for (see
here) and could lead to further USD strength.
ii. The TV Debates on the 4th (VP), 9th and 19th of October will be
watched closely by markets, too.
 BOE QIR meeting – 11 November
i. Q3 GDP and the data around it will set the tone going into the BOE
meeting. From where we are now, it would take a more severe outlook
change in the data for the BOE to act again, in our view (see here).
 Autumn fiscal statement – 23 November
i. There are expectations that Philip Hammond could start on a fiscal
stimulus in the autumn statement (link).
 Italian Constitutional Referendum – 4 December
i. A ‘no’ vote would increase uncertainty. However, looking at various
scenarios, we conclude that rejection of the constitutional reforms is
unlikely to trigger an election. This means that, while the market
reaction is likely to be asymmetric and much bigger in the case of a
‘no’ vote, Italian bonds and EUR are likely to sell off on the result (l

BE

Seadrill Partners announced yesterday that it has received a notice of Force Majeure from Tullow for the West Leo drilling contract effective from 3 October. The drilling contractor disputes Tullow's claim for Force Majeure and intends to enforce all its rights as per the contract, which includes a $605k/day rate that extends June 2018.
The West Leo has most recently been employed on the TEN development project in Ghana. This field is subject to a drilling moratorium by the government of Ghana due to the ongoing arbitration proceedings before the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea ("ITLOS") to determine the delineation of a disputed border, and as a result the previously planned infill drilling campaign has been deferred. And, a switch to drilling on the nearby Jubilee field does not look viable at this stage as the necessary permits are not in place for the full-field development, and the issues with the turret are delaying any need for additional well capacity. Given these issues we had previously excluded the 2017-18 portion of the drilling contract from our Tullow NAV.
